title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the number of trout (per kilometer) less than 1 year old downstream from the dam in 1999 as 2,440.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the relationship between dam removal and the number of trout (per kilometer) older than 1 year upstream of the dam, such as any of the following:

· After the removal of the dam, the number of trout older than 1 year increased upstream of the dam.

· The dam removal allowed the trout to swim upstream past the dam, increasing their population size.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe an environmental factor other than dam removal that could account for the variability in population size seen between years 2011 and 2016 in trout younger than 1 year, such as any of the following:

· Decrease in predators, leading to an increase in population size.

· Increase in food supply for trout could increase survivability of trout.

· Increased precipitation could have increased water flow, resulting in more suitable habitat on the river.

The response describes an environmental factor other than dam removal that could account for the variability in population size seen between years 2011 and 2016 in trout younger than 1 year, such as one of the following:

· Decrease in predators, leading to an increase in population size.

· Increase in food supply for trout could increase survivability of trout.

· Increased precipitation could have increased water flow, resulting in more suitable habitat on the river.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain why the number of species sensitive to changes in water quality and water level decreased the year after dam removal, such as any of the following:

· Increased turbidity from change in river flow can harm sensitive species.

· Change in temperature due to change in depth of river can harm sensitive species.

· Release of pollutants trapped in sediments upstream of river may harm sensitive species.

· The dam removal eliminated or reduced habitat for some aquatic species when the river flow changed.

· The dam removal changed the habitat that was previously downstream or upstream of the dam, decreasing the number of species.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how overpumping water for irrigation could affect the aquifer shown in the diagram, such as any of the following:

· Overpumping could cause the water table to drop/deplete groundwater stores.

· Overpumping could cause saltwater intrusion near coastal areas.

· Overpumping could cause the land surface above the aquifer to subside/create a sinkhole compacting soil and making aquifer recharge difficult.

· Pollutants present in groundwater could become more concentrated as volume of water in aquifer decreases.

The response describes how overpumping water for irrigation could affect the aquifer shown in the diagram, such as one of the following:

· Overpumping could cause the water table to drop/deplete groundwater stores.

· Overpumping could cause saltwater intrusion near coastal areas.

· Overpumping could cause the land surface above the aquifer to subside/create a sinkhole compacting soil and making aquifer recharge difficult.

· Pollutants present in groundwater could become more concentrated as volume of water in aquifer decreases.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one sustainable approach for grazing beef cattle, such as any of the following:

· Shift cattle to different portions of a field to allow time for fields to fallow.

· Reduce the number of animals grazing/herd size.

· Allow cattle to roam in open areas rather than confining them in small pens.

· Free range grazing allow waste to be fertilize the soils, reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.

· Rotational grazing of cattle on different pastures will avoid overgrazing/desertification or erosion.

· Cattle allowed to free range will not require antibiotic use.

The response describes one sustainable approach for grazing beef cattle, such as one of the following:

· Shift cattle to different portions of a field to allow time for fields to fallow.

· Reduce the number of animals grazing/herd size.

· Allow cattle to roam in open areas rather than confining them in small pens.

· Free range grazing allow waste to be fertilize the soils, reducing the need for synthetic fertilizers.

· Rotational grazing of cattle on different pastures will avoid overgrazing/desertification or erosion.

· Cattle allowed to free range will not require antibiotic use.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem migratory waterfowl species may experience, because of the increased need for agricultural land for meat production, such as any of the following:

· Increased use of wild land for feed crop production removes habitats/resting stops for migratory birds.

· Fecal coliform contamination from grazing land or feed lots may contaminate the water used by migratory birds.

· Water usage needed for feed crops for meat production may deplete water available in nearby rivers and wetlands, decreasing habitat/resting stops for migratory birds.

The response describes one environmental problem migratory waterfowl species may experience, because of the increased need for agricultural land for meat production, such as one of the following:

· Increased use of wild land for feed crop production removes habitats/resting stops for migratory birds.

· Fecal coliform contamination from grazing land or feed lots may contaminate the water used by migratory birds.

· Water usage needed for feed crops for meat production may deplete water available in nearby rivers and wetlands, decreasing habitat/resting stops for migratory birds.
